snippet.title: An iconic shirt Frank Ocean wore in concert has sold thousands for an independent shop, but the idea for it was stolen
snippet.content:
Frank Ocean gave a great performance at last Friday, but the resulting discussion around his set has centered not so much on his music - or the fact that filmmaker Spike Jonze filmed the show - but on the instantly iconic T-shirt that Ocean wore during the performance.
"Why be racist, sexist, homophobic or transphobic when you could just be quiet?" Ocean's plain-white shirt read, in capitalised black lettering.
As reports, the shirt was produced by , an independent online shop founded in 2016 by 18-year-old Kayla Robinson.
Over the weekend following Ocean's performance, the shirt became a viral hit on Twitter, and Robinson's site flooded with 5,500 overall purchases - a massive boon compared to her typical two-day sales of 100 orders.
The Times story goes on to detail, however, that the text of the shirt originated from the following August 2015 tweet, written by 18-year-old Brandon Male:
Male said he contacted Green Box Shop about the shirt earlier this year, and they initially disregarded him. After the shirt blew up following Ocean's performance, Robinson reportedly sent Male $US100 via Venmo - less than 1% of the revenue gained from the $US18.99 shirts in two days.
"It was an impulsive decision," Robinson told the Times. "I hadn't looked at the number of sales, and I wasn't thinking about it portionwise. It does look like I was just throwing money at him to keep him quiet."
Male could have filed a cease-and-desist against Green Box for using his tweet without his permission. Instead, the two parties have since agreed to avoid the nebulous waters of by sitting down to negotiate a proportional profit for both sides.
